instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
hi Guys
I'm new here and could use a little help.
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A board and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> is not present.
USB-C AmpMeter says 20V and pulsing 6 and 60 mA
 The board has no water damage and no corrosion. All components that have to do with <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> look good but I have 0.5 ohms to ground sounds like a short for me I think this board has dead CPU
maybe one of you can help me out with this or can anyone confirm my thoughts of a bad CPU

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> is dedicated power rail for PCH.
0.5 ohm resistance to ground is low enough to use voltage injection method.
Start with 1V and slowly go high (no more than 4V), if needed.
Set first amp limit to lab PSU at max.

Do you get correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> (L7690)?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 13.02V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: Is pulsing between 0 and 3.3V (maybe I've overlooked this before but I remember <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> at L7690 was stable last time I measured it)

i inject 3.3V into <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> but I don't notice a change nothing gets hot at this time

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> missing
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> missing
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
"Start with 1V and slowly go high (no more than 4V), if needed.
Set first amp limit to lab PSU at max."
Injecting 3.3V directly can block PSU and it will not inject anything instead.
0.5 ohm will sink more than 6A from 3.3V!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
first of all, thank you for your help and your time
Today I tried again inject voltage into <SIGNAL>3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> and cpu was getting clearly hot hat 2,2v and 3,5A 
i think that confirms my thought of a dead cpu ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: Exactly, 7.7W is high enough to heat it...
